<heading>INTRODUCTION AND KEY TO THE GUIANAN MISTLETOE FAMILIES</heading>

The basically Euro-centered view of all mistletoes contained in a single family, LORANTHACEAE, proved to be unacceptable by the second half of the 20th Century. All specialists since the 1960's have been in agreement that two major natural taxa exist, viz., LORANTHACEAE s.s. and VISCACEAE (Barlow 1964, Kuijt 1968). The major distinction between the two families is the presence of a calyculus (usually interpreted as a reduced calyx) in LORANTHACEAE only, the flower thus being dichlamydeous in contrast to the monochlamydeous Viscacean flower with a single floral whorl. In addition, there are embryological, chromosomal, and other distinctions (Kuijt 1969).
It appears that LORANTHACEAE s.s. are of southern origin while VISCACEAE probably originated in the Northern Hemisphere (Barlow & Wiens 1971, Wiens & Barlow 1971). The great majority of LORANTHACEAE (nearly all the Old World genera) are predominantly bird-pollinated and have large, colorful flowers, but no VISCACEAE appear to be.
Awareness of the

exsistence of other groups of Santalalean arboreal parasites has further complicated the taxonomic conception of "mistletoe". In southeastern Asia, several groups of SANTALACEAE parasitize branches of woody hosts; especially striking is the squamate genus Phacellaria which, at first sight, might well be mistaken for an Arceuthobium of VISCACEAE. The extraordinary MISODENDRACEAE of southern S America must similarly be thought of as being mistletoe-like in habit. Thus the conception of "mistletoe" within SANTALALES has assumed a more ecological rather than precise taxonomic cachet, signifying plants which parasitized branches of woody hosts. Ironically, even this circumscription cannot adequately cover LORANTHACEAE s.s., as its most primitive trio of genera (Atkinsonia, Nuytsia, and Gaiadendron) are terrestrial root-parasites, only the latter having the ability to "ascend" a host tree, where it parasitizes fellow epiphytes, probably exclusively (Kuijt 1963).
The above resumé does not exhaust contemporary controversy. A distinctive group of 3 genera (Antidaphne, Eubrachion, and Lepidoceras) which has traditionally been placed in VISCACEAE (or LORANTHACEAE subfam. VISCOIDEAE) were treated as a separate family, EREMOLEPIDACEAE (Kuijt, 1988). There is general agreement today that this is a natural assemblage, but molecular information has been promoted to indicate that EREMOLEPIDACEAE — and even VISCACEAE! — are better placed in SANTALACEAE, these ideas already having been incorporated in the third edition of Maas & Westra's "Neotropical plant families". Since such an alignment to me appears to be neither justified nor useful, the treatment which follows continues to recognize three families of mistletoes in the Guianas.

<keyTitle>KEY TO THE FAMILIES OF GUIANAN MISTLETOES</keyTitle>

<text>Leafy plants; flowers often large and colorful, then (3-)5- or 6-merous, bi- or unisexual, ovary topped by a calyculus; inflorescence spicate, racemose, or umbellate, flowers often pedicellate and/or in triads/dyads and provided with bracteoles</text>

<text>Leafy or squamate plants; flowers small and greenish, unisexual, 2- to 4-merous, ovary lacking a calyculus; inflorescences spicate, flowers sessile, ebracteolate, not in triads but often spread along, and sunken in internodes of spike</text>
<text>Leafy or squamate plants; flowers sunken into inflorescence axis, often in longitudinal series along inflorescence internodes; inflorescences usually axillary; leaves decussate</text>
<text>Squamate plants; flowers not sunken into inflorescence axis, solitary in axils of scale leaves; inflorescences at tips of branches; leaves alternate</text>
<char class="habit">Semiparasitic mistletoes on branches of shrubs and trees, some with epicortical roots at base of plant,
<subChar class="primary haustoria">primary haustorium often becoming large and saddle-like. </subChar>
<char class="leaves">Leaves alternate, simple, short-petiolate to nearly sessile, expanded or scale-like and peltate. </char>

<subChar class="flowers">flowers pedicellate or sessile, apetalous in male <fullName rank="genus">Antidaphne</fullName> only, where with central glandular disk and <subChar class="stamen number">2-4</subChar> stamens. </subChar>
<subChar class="flowers">flowers with <subChar class="perianth segment number">2 or 3</subChar> minute, caducous perianth segments. </subChar>
<char class="fruits">Fruit a small, <subChar class="seed number">1-seeded</subChar> berry;
<subChar class="seeds">seed with abundant, <subChar class="endosperm colour">whitish</subChar> endosperm.</subChar>

<string><subHeading>Distribution:</subHeading> A strictly American family ranging from <distributionLocality class="state">Oaxaca</distributionLocality> in <distributionLocality class="country">Mexico</distributionLocality> to <distributionLocality class="region">northern Argentina</distributionLocality> and <distributionLocality class="region">southern Chile</distributionLocality>, as well as the <distributionLocality class="region">Greater Antilles</distributionLocality>, with 3 small genera totalling perhaps 12 species; in the <distributionLocality class="region">Guianas</distributionLocality> 1 species.</string>

<string><subHeading>Note:</subHeading> In addition to the genus here included, it is conceivable that <fullName rank="species">Eubrachion gracile Kuijt</fullName> occurs in the mid-western portion of Guyana, at elevations between 1400 and 2300 m. It is a slender, erect, squamate, monoecious mistletoe with small, cone-like inflorescences. It appears to be a Venezuelan endemic known mostly from the Auyan-tepui area about 100 km W of the Guyana border.</string>
<subChar class="epicortical roots">basal epicortical roots present, with both primary and secondary haustoria. </subChar>
<char class="leaves">Leaves alternate, simple, variable in shape, shiny and <subChar class="texture">somewhat leathery</subChar> when fresh. </char>

<string><subHeading>Distribution:</subHeading> 7 or 8 species, ranging from <distributionLocality class="country">Mexico</distributionLocality> (<distributionLocality class="state">Oaxaca</distributionLocality>) to <distributionLocality class="region">southern Chile</distributionLocality>, 1 species being endemic to <distributionLocality class="region" status="endemic">Cuba</distributionLocality> and <distributionLocality class="region" status="endemic">Hispaniola</distributionLocality>; 1 species in the <distributionLocality class="region">Guianas</distributionLocality>.</string>

<specimenType><gathering>Type: <locality class="locality">Venezuela, Distr. Federal, Depto. Libertador</locality><collector>Steyermark</collector><fieldNum>127742</fieldNum><collectionAndType>(neotype MO, designated by Kuijt 1988:
<char class="habit">Plants to <subChar class="diameter">ca. 1.5 m in diam.</subChar> </char>

<subChar class="epicortical roots">epicortical roots present at least when young, |, bearing conspicuous secondary haustoria; <subChar class="colour">brownish</subChar>, bearing conspicuous secondary haustoria; </subChar>
<subChar class="haustoria">primary haustorium becoming large, often fusing with adjacent secondary haustoria in age. </subChar>
<char class="leaves">Leaves sessile or with short, indistinct petiole;
<subChar class="blade">blade <subChar class="shape">mostly obovate with rounded apex</subChar>. </subChar>
<char class="male inflorescences">Male inflorescence a racemose catkin with caducous scales, <subChar class="terminal leaves">terminal leaves absent</subChar>. </char>
inflorescence with minute leaves which may later expand and become foliaceous; </subChar>
<subChar class="female inflorescences">female inflorescence usually elongating after anthesis. </subChar>
<char class="fruits">Fruit <subChar class="colour">grey-green to whitish or yellowish</subChar>, <subChar class="length">ca. 0.4 cm long</subChar>.</char>

<string><subHeading>Distribution:</subHeading> <distributionLocality class="country">Mexico</distributionLocality> (<distributionLocality class="state">Oaxaca</distributionLocality>) to the <distributionLocality class="region">Andes of northern Bolivia</distributionLocality>, <distributionLocality class="region">northern and eastern Venezuela</distributionLocality>. In the <distributionLocality class="region">Guianas</distributionLocality> known from a single collection from the <distributionLocality class="region">Cuyuni-Mazaruni Region</distributionLocality> of <distributionLocality class="country">Guyana</distributionLocality> (Pipoly et al. 10686 (LEA, NY)). The plant is very inconspicuous, however, and should be looked for elsewhere (GU: 1).</string>
<char class="habit">Leafy shrubs parasitic on other woody plants. </char>
<char class="epicortical roots">Epicortical roots in a number of species, mostly at base, sometimes also from stems. </char>
<subChar class="flowers">flowers mostly in monads, dyads, or triads with fused bracts and/or bracteoles. </subChar>
<char class="flowers">Flowers mostly perfect, dioecious in some species, then flowers with aborted organs of opposite sex;
<subChar class="calyx">calyx reduced to a very inconspicuous calyculus; </subChar>

<subChar class="petals">petals conspicuous, |, fused or not, often brightly colored when flower perfect; <subChar class="petal number">(3-)4-7</subChar>, fused or not, often brightly colored when flower perfect; </subChar>
<subChar class="anthers">anthers dorsi- or basifixed, mostly dimorphic; </subChar>
<subChar class="style">style in many genera slender and long. </subChar>
<char class="fruits">Fruit a <subChar class="seed number">1-seeded</subChar> berry of diverse colors and size;
<subChar class="seeds">seed endospermous in all but Psittacanthus. </subChar>

<string><subHeading>Distribution:</subHeading> About 700 species distributed over some 60 genera, largely in the <distributionLocality class="world">tropics and subtropics of all continents</distributionLocality>; 15 genera in the <distributionLocality class="world">New World</distributionLocality>; 37 species in 8 genera in the <distributionLocality class="region">Guianas</distributionLocality>.</string>

Notes: In the majority of New World LORANTHACEAE, stamens are of 2 sets, inserted at different heights on the subtending petals, reaching different heights, and often of somewhat different shapes. This is true even for such small-flowered genera as Oryctanthus, Oryctina, and Phthirusa. Additionally, some species exhibit considerable sexual dimorphism, non-functional stamens being present in female flowers and a non-functional style in the male.
Loranthus patrisii DC. (Prodr. 4: 288. 1830) does not belong to the Loranthaceae. Its type (French Guiana, Patris s.n., G-DC) is a species of Combretum (Combretaceae), probably C. laxum Jacq.

<text>Flowers 6(-7)-merous, petals 0.1 cm to several cm long</text>
<text>Inflorescence determinate, single terminal flower following at least one pair of monads</text>
<text>Inflorescence indeterminate (i.e., lacking a terminal flower), consisting of lateral, bracteolate triads only</text>
<text>Flowers usually bright yellow (not red), each subtended by a separate green, foliar bract(eole); known from Mt. Roraima summit only</text>
<text>Flowers not bright yellow, and not separately subtended by foliar bract(eole)s; diverse localities</text>
<text>Inflorescence with lateral monads only, including sessile monads</text>
<text>Inflorescence with lateral triads or dyads only</text>
<text>Flowers mostly partially immersed in inflorescence axis, each flanked by 2 strap-like, nearly obscured, bracteoles; pollen with 3 prominent excavations on each face</text>
<text>Flowers not immersed in inflorescence axis; bracteoles not strap-like, ca. boat-shaped, largely exposed; pollen lacking prominent excavations</text>
<text>Petals > 4 cm long, usually reddish or red and yellow; seed lacking endosperm</text>
<text>Petals < 2 cm long, white, cream-colored or red; seed with endosperm</text>
<text>Anthers basifixed, longer filaments laterally excavated to accommodate lower anthers</text>
<text>Anthers dorsifixed, versatile, filaments slender, not laterally excavated</text>
<text>Triads and flowers stalked; anthers dorsifixed, versatile</text>
<text>Triads and flowers sessile or essentially so; anthers basifixed, longer filaments laterally excavated to accommodate lower anthers</text>
<char class="habit">Small plants, glabrous to furfuraceous when young;
<subChar class="epicortical roots">at least sometimes with a few slender epicortical roots from base of plant. </subChar>

<char class="inflorescences">Inflorescences determinate or indeterminate, extremely small, often (but not always) with bracteolate triads below and ebracteolate monads above, all but terminal flowers in paired
<subChar class="stamens">stamens/anthers fused with subtending petals, dimorphic, with <subChar class="pollen sac number">2 or 4</subChar> pollen sacs.</subChar>

<string><subHeading>Distribution:</subHeading> About 40 species, mostly <distributionLocality class="region">Central Mexico</distributionLocality>, <distributionLocality class="continental region">S America</distributionLocality> to <distributionLocality class="region">northern Peru</distributionLocality> and <distributionLocality class="country">Bolivia</distributionLocality>; in the <distributionLocality class="region">Guianas</distributionLocality> 3 species.</string>
<text>Flowers 3-4-merous, leaves dull, with inconspicuous to obscure venation</text>
<text>Anther a thin structure with 4 minute pollen sacs at its corners, completely fused with petal</text>

<char class="habit">Plants with several slender epicortical roots from base;
<subChar class="juvenile stems">young stem and inflorescence |, furfuraceous; <subChar class="colour">brown</subChar>, furfuraceous; </subChar>
<subChar class="blade">blade extremely variable, <subChar class="shape">lanceolate, elliptic, or ovate</subChar>, <subChar class="dimensions">to 8 x 3.5 cm</subChar>,
<subChar class="apex">apex rounded to deeply emarginate, usually minutely apiculate, </subChar>
<subChar class="veins">venation ranging from pinnate with a distinct midvein reaching into apex to 3-veined in more emarginate leaves. </subChar>
<char class="plant sexuality">Dioecious, male plants apparently infrequent. </char>

<char class="inflorescences">Inflorescence determinate, |, apical flower followed by one or more pairs of bracteolate or ebracteolate, sessile monads, below which sometimes <subChar class="length">0.5-3 cm long</subChar>, apical flower followed by one or more pairs of bracteolate or ebracteolate, sessile monads, below which sometimes <subChar class="triad pair number">one or more pairs</subChar>
<subChar class="peduncle">peduncle |, often elongating in fruit; <subChar class="length">0.1 cm</subChar>, often elongating in fruit; </subChar>
<subChar class="secondary inflorescences">secondary inflorescences frequent in a superposed position; </subChar>

<subChar class="compound inflorescences">vigorous plants also with whip-like |, where |, awl-shaped scale leaves of <subChar class="terminal inflorescences">terminal, compound inflorescence <subChar class="length">to 15 (-20) cm long</subChar></subChar>, where <subChar class="lateral inflorescences">lateral inflorescences subtended by caducous, <subChar class="texture">fleshy</subChar>, awl-shaped scale leaves of <subChar class="length">0.2-0.3 cm long</subChar></subChar>. </subChar>
<char class="flowers">Male and female flowers similar, <subChar class="merosity">3- or 4-merous</subChar>, <subChar class="length">< 0.2 cm long</subChar>;
<subChar class="petals and stamens">petals and stamens slightly dimorphic, organs of opposite sex small,

<char class="fruits">Fruit <subChar class="shape">ellipsoid or ovoid</subChar>, <subChar class="dimensions">0.5 x 0.3 cm</subChar>, <subChar class="colour">light orange to red with dark tip</subChar>.</char>

<string><subHeading>Distribution:</subHeading> <distributionLocality class="country">Venezuela</distributionLocality> (<distributionLocality class="state">Bolívar</distributionLocality>) through the <distributionLocality class="region">Guianas</distributionLocality> and into <distributionLocality class="region">northern Brazil</distributionLocality>; 30+ collections studied, 16 from the <distributionLocality class="region">Guianas</distributionLocality> (GU: 14; SU: 1; FG: 1).</string>

<gathering><locality class="locality">Rupununi Distr., Shea Rock</locality>, <collector>Jansen-Jacobs et al.</collector> <fieldNum>3697</fieldNum> <collectionAndType>(LEA, U)</collectionAndType></gathering>; <gathering><locality class="locality">Upper Takutu-Upper Essequibo Region, Acarai Mts.</locality>, <collector>Clarke et

<gathering><locality class="locality">Piste de Saint-Elie, Interfluve Sinnamary-Counamama</locality>, <collector>Prévost et al.</collector> <fieldNum>3408</fieldNum> <collectionAndType>(CAY, LEA, NY, K, MO)</collectionAndType></gathering>.

Notes: Plants with larger, strictly pinnately veined leaves are very similar to Phthirusa guyanensis, which has indeterminate inflorescences occasionally elongating to 6 cm, the bracts and bracteoles forming a more united, densely furfuraceous cupule, and on which members of triad pairs tend to become widely separated from each other.
Cladocolea elliptica is believed to fall within the considerable range of variability of C. micrantha; its stated indeterminate inflorescences need to be confirmed. There is a form of the species with extremely narrow, lanceolate leaves with acute leaf base.

<string><subHeading>Note:</subHeading> Characteristic as a small terrestrial tree at the lower edges of práramo vegetation in most of its range but, in its "epiphytic" form (when parasitic on other epiphytes), may also occur at somewhat lower levels in context of moist forests.</string>
<char class="habit">Leafy parasitic shrubs, glabrous but young twigs often strongly furfuraceous;
<subChar class="epicortical roots">epicortical roots from base of plant but not from stems, sometimes lacking at least at maturity. </subChar>
<subChar class="veins">venation palmate or pinnate, containing characteristic stellate fiber bundles along smaller veins. </subChar>
<subChar class="position">solitary in leaf axil or sometimes clustered, sometimes arranged in a terminal, compound, squamate inflorescence</subChar>
<subChar class="flowers">flowers sessile in cavities of often swollen axis, each flower subtended by 2 minute, acute, strap-shaped bracteoles. </subChar>
<char class="flowers">Flowers bisexual, small, <subChar class="merosity">6-merous (in the Guianas species)</subChar>, <subChar class="colour">yellow to dark red</subChar>;
<subChar class="petals and stamens">petals and stamens dimorphic; </subChar>
<subChar class="pollen">pollen with 3 circular depressions on each face; </subChar>
<subChar class="style">style straight, with scarcely differentiated stigma. </subChar>
<char class="fruits">Fruit <subChar class="colour">green, yellow-green, red to purple or black</subChar>;
<subChar class="mature seeds">mature seed with |, dicotylous embryo,
<subChar class="cotyledons">cotyledons massive, haustorial disk well differentiated.</subChar>

<string><subHeading>Distribution:</subHeading> <distributionLocality class="region">Southern Mexico</distributionLocality> ( <distributionLocality class="state">Tabasco</distributionLocality> & <distributionLocality class="state">Chiapas</distributionLocality>), through <distributionLocality class="continental region">Central America</distributionLocality> to <distributionLocality class="region">north-eastern Bolivia</distributionLocality> and the <distributionLocality class="region">northern half of Brazil</distributionLocality>, with a population of <fullName rank="species">O. occidentalis</fullName> on <distributionLocality class="region">Jamaica</distributionLocality>; taxonomically distinctive genus with 11 often inconspicuous species; 3 in the <distributionLocality class="region">Guianas</distributionLocality>.</string>

<string><subHeading>Notes:</subHeading> In addition to the 3 species treated below, it is possible that <fullName rank="species">O. spicatus (Jacq.) Eichler</fullName> also occurs in the Guianas. It is very close to <fullName rank="species">O. florulentus</fullName> (in fact, it may intergrade with it W of the Guianas) but is more slender and usually smaller,

its spikes having rather long and slender peduncles, and its fruits somewhat smaller and more rounded at the tip.
An additional species, O. cordifolius (C. Presl) Urb., was previously reported for Guyana (Kuijt 1976), but this appears to be an error.

<string><subHeading>Distribution:</subHeading> Uncertain number of species (see note below); almost exclusively continental, <distributionLocality class="continental region">S America</distributionLocality>n genus (2 species on <distributionLocality class="region">Jamaica</distributionLocality>), ranging from <distributionLocality class="region">southern Mexico</distributionLocality> to <distributionLocality class="country">Bolivia</distributionLocality>, only <fullName rank="species">P. pyrifolia</fullName> being present <distributionLocality class="region">north of Costa Rica</distributionLocality>; in the <distributionLocality class="region">Guianas</distributionLocality> 11 species.</string>
<string><subHeading>Habitat:</subHeading> <habitat>there is a strong preference for <altitude>low elevations</altitude> in <fullName rank="genus">Phthirusa</fullName>.</habitat></string>

<string><subHeading>Note:</subHeading> The closely related, strictly Caribbean genus Dendropemon (Blume) Rchb. has in the past frequently been synonymized under <fullName rank="genus">Phthirusa</fullName>. The present genus is of uncertain size as it has not been analyzed properly since Eichler's treatment in the Flora Brasiliensis in 1868; it is probably not a natural assemblage. Its separation from <fullName rank="genus">Struthanthus</fullName> is said to be difficult, but this is perhaps due to the lack of attention to the details of floral structure; no <fullName rank="genus">Phthirusa</fullName> species has slender filaments and versatile anthers, as is the case in <fullName rank="genus">Struthanthus</fullName>. Anther morphology in the two genera would seem to be very different, those of <fullName rank="genus">Struthanthus</fullName> being dorsifixed and versatile, those of <fullName rank="genus">Phthirusa</fullName> being basifixed (sometimes sessile), the connective of some species extending into a small horn and the filament massive and laterally excavated (longer stamen series). See also the comments under Struthanthus.</string>
<refPart class="pubtitle">Inflorescence structure and generic placement of some small-flowered species of Phthirusa (Loranthaceae)</refPart>

<text>Inflorescence peduncles terete or only slightly angled</text>
<text>Inflorescence axis strongly brown-furfuraceous; leaf apex acute, base truncate or nearly so; dioecious</text>
<text>Inflorescence axis glabrous or no more than very thinly furfuraceous; leaf apex acute to rounded, base obtuse to acute; dioecious or flowers bisexual</text>
<text>Flowers bisexual; epicortical roots from base only; stems compressed or even keeled when young, with furfuraceous lines</text>
<text>Plants dioecious; epicortical roots from base and at least sometimes from stem; young stems no more than slightly compressed, not keeled, lacking furfuraceous lines</text>

<text>Leaves broadly ovate, base usually obtuse; inflorescence with to 12 or more pairs of triads</text>

<text>Inflorescence a (mostly pedunculate) spike or raceme; flowers (3-) 4-merous</text>
<text>Members of a triad pair often separated along elongating inflorescence axis; triad bract broad, investing base of fruit; leaves thin, often mucronate or emarginate</text>

<string><subHeading>Note:</subHeading> Superficially somewhat similar to <fullName rank="species">P. coarctata</fullName>. The latter species, however, has distinct bracts and bracteoles, while those of <fullName rank="species">P. disjectifolia</fullName> are fused in cupulate fashion. Additionally, these 'cupules' in <fullName rank="species">P. disjectifolia</fullName> fall away as a unit after the fruits are gone, leaving the lower spike naked, while the bracts and bracteoles of <fullName rank="species">P. coarctata</fullName> persist. In the latter, 2-loculate and 4-loculate anthers alternate, but <fullName rank="species">P. disjectifolia</fullName> seems to have 2-loculate anthers only.</string>

<char class="habit">Scandent plants, epicortical roots at base and occasionally from stems;
<subChar class="juvenile internodes">young internodes slightly compressed, becoming terete, glabrous or essentially so. </subChar>
<subChar class="blade">blade often <subChar class="colour">yellowish or light green</subChar>, <subChar class="shape">broadly ovate</subChar>, <subChar class="dimensions">to 14 x 7.5 cm</subChar>,
<subChar class="apex">apex usually attenuate and base obtuse. </subChar>

<char class="inflorescences">Inflorescence |, in the former case always and in the latter case often compound, consisting of a terminal raceme plus <subChar class="position">both terminal and axillary</subChar>, in the former case always and in the latter case often compound, consisting of a terminal raceme plus <subChar class="lower lateral raceme number">2-6</subChar> lower, lateral racemes each with <subChar class="triad pair number">about 12 pairs</subChar> of evenly spaced triads, compound inflorescence <subChar class="length">to 15 cm</subChar>

<subChar class="triad peduncle">triad peduncle |, terminating in a bract and <subChar class="length">to 0.2 cm</subChar>, terminating in a bract and <subChar class="bracteole number">2</subChar> bracteoles of about equal size, these persisting, acute, subtending <subChar class="flower number per bracteole">1</subChar> sessile flower each. </subChar>
<char class="flower buds">Flower bud |, female rather acute and narrow, male blunt. <subChar class="length">to 0.6 cm long</subChar>, female rather acute and narrow, male blunt. </char>
class="petals">Petals <subChar class="colour">whitish yellow to light red</subChar>;
<subChar class="aborted organs">aborted organs well differentiated in flowers of opposite sex; </subChar>
<subChar class="anthers">anther connective forming small, terminal horn. </subChar>
<char class="fruits">Fruit <subChar class="colour">brick red to orange</subChar>, <subChar class="shape">ellipsoid</subChar>, <subChar class="dimensions">to 1 x 0.5 cm</subChar>.</char>

<string><subHeading>Distribution:</subHeading> As defined here, <fullName rank="species">P. stelis</fullName> ranges from <distributionLocality class="country">Costa Rica</distributionLocality> through most of <distributionLocality class="continental region">lowland tropical S America</distributionLocality>, on the <distributionLocality class="region">east side of the Andes south to Bolivia</distributionLocality>; many hundreds of collections studied, at least 120 from the <distributionLocality class="region">Guianas</distributionLocality> (GU: 25+; SU: 6; FG: 30+).</string>

<subChar class="peduncle">peduncle |, followed by <subChar class="length">0.2-0.5 cm</subChar>, followed by <subChar class="triad pair number">1 or 2 pairs</subChar> of triads; </subChar>

<string><subHeading>Note:</subHeading> Inclusion of this species is based on a single collection (Henkel et al. 762 (LEA)), providing the above diagnosis which closely parallels the protologue, in which the stamens are shown to be of the same type as that in, for example, <fullName rank="species">P. pyrifolia</fullName>. It is clearly an extremely rare species, of uncertain distribution; its type originated in southern Amazonas. The species may be confused with the very narrow-leaved form of <fullName rank="species">Cladocolea micrantha</fullName> which, however, has furfuraceous stems and 4-merous flowers.</string>
<char class="habit">Very small and delicate species, haustorial saddle |, lacking epicortical roots;
<subChar class="internodes">internodes terete, <subChar class="length">mostly less than 1 cm long</subChar>. </subChar>
<subChar class="blade">blade <subChar class="texture">very thin</subChar>, <subChar class="shape">lanceolate</subChar> <subChar class="dimensions">to 1.5 x 0.8 cm</subChar>; </subChar>

<char class="inflorescences">Inflorescence |, with extremely slender, pubescent peduncle and <subChar class="length">ca. 0.5 cm long, to 1 cm in fruit</subChar>, with extremely slender, pubescent peduncle and <subChar class="triad number">2</subChar> sessile triads at tip, in umbellate fashion. </char>
<subChar class="petals">petals <subChar class="petal number">4</subChar>, <subChar class="length">ca. 0.1 cm long</subChar>; </subChar>

<char class="fruits">Fruit |, with small, smooth, <subChar class="shape">ellipsoid</subChar>, <subChar class="dimensions">0.4 x 0.2 cm</subChar>, with small, smooth, <subChar class="growth form">erect</subChar> calyculus.</char>

<char class="inflorescences">Inflorescences indeterminate racemes or umbels of triads or dyads, <subChar class="position">former in terminal or subterminal positions, latter axillary</subChar>. </char>

<char class="flowers">Flowers large, mostly pedicellate (sessile in <fullName rank="species">P. cucullaris</fullName>), subtended by <subChar class="bract and bracteole number">1</subChar> bract or bracteole each; bisexual, <subChar class="merosity">6-merous</subChar>, <subChar class="colour">usually brightly colored in red or red and yellow</subChar>;
<subChar class="petals and stamens">petals and stamens dimorphic, rarely isomorphic; </subChar>
<subChar class="petals">petals long, slender, fused to varying length, bearing epipetalous stamens consisting of slender filaments,
<subChar class="anthers">anthers dorsifixed, mostly versatile, <subChar class="locule number">4-loculate</subChar>. </subChar>

<subChar class="seeds">seed consisting mostly of a massive, fleshy <subChar class="colour">green</subChar> seedling with <subChar class="cotyledon number">2 or more</subChar> large, fleshy cotyledons,

<string><subHeading>Distribution:</subHeading> Mostly <distributionLocality class="region">continental, northwestern Mexico</distributionLocality> (including <distributionLocality class="region">central Baja California</distributionLocality>) to <distributionLocality class="country">Argentina</distributionLocality>; a large genus of ca. 120 species; in the <distributionLocality class="region">Guianas</distributionLocality> 12 species.</string>

<string><subHeading>Note:</subHeading> A possibly additional species not included separately below is present in the Matoroni R. area of French Guiana, where flowers were collected from the ground (Mori et al. 25307, LEA; see the citation under <fullName rank="species">P. clusiifolius</fullName>). Its petals are nearly twice as long (12-13 cm) as those of the latter species, the stigma much larger and strikingly papillate; and the thick, rapidly tapering filament is flanked by tufts of long, red hairs — features missing in <fullName rank="species">P. clusiifolius</fullName>. The plant may represent an undescribed species.</string>

<text>Inflorescence a double triad (umbel of 2 triads) or raceme of dyads or triads</text>
<text>Flowers sessile at tip of triad peduncle; ovary completely immersed in an elongated, tubular cupule; bract broad, foliar</text>
<text>Flowers pedicellate; ovary at least partly emergent from cupule or fused bracteoles; bract not foliar</text>
<text>Leaves sessile, base cordate, clasping the stem</text>
<text>Inflorescences placed at branch tips, each a raceme; leaves similar on both sides; shoot tip aborting; stamens isomorphic, filaments 4-5 mm long, thick</text>

<text>Inflorescences axillary along shoot, each a double dyad; stamens dimorphic, overlapping for half their length; lower leaf surface brownish; shoot tips not aborting; filaments 7-8 mm long, thin</text>
<text>Internodes angular when young; bud apex acute; stamens nearly isomorphic, with red hairs</text>
<text>Internodes terete when young; bud apex obtuse to rounded; stamens dimorphic, lacking hairs</text>
<text>Buds and inflorescence branches very stout; inflorescence a terminal raceme of triads; petals fleshy, to 6.3 cm long, with smooth margins</text>
<text>Buds and inflorescence branches not stout; inflorescences axillary, each a double dyad; petals not fleshy, < 4.5 cm long, with crenate margins</text>
<text>Leaf apex acute; buds no more than very short-hairy; midrib prominent, reaching leaf apex</text>
<text>Leaf apex rounded; buds densely brown-hairy; midrib not prominent, not reaching leaf apex</text>
<text>Leaf apex acute; petal tips black, usually recurved somewhat even in bud, with granular surface, basal ligules hairy</text>
<text>Leaf apex rounded; petal tips not black or recurved, glabrous, basal ligules absent</text>
<text>Petals to 7.5 cm long, filiform; filaments 3.5-4 cm long</text>
<text>Petals < 4.5 cm long, not filiform; filaments < 1.5 cm long</text>
<text>Leaves broadly ovate to lanceolate, venation evident; buds strongly curved; anthers lacking hairs</text>
<text>Leaves ovate, flat and leathery, venation rather obscure; buds straight; anthers with long red hairs</text>

<string><subHeading>Note:</subHeading> This species is closely related to <fullName rank="species">P. lamprophyllus Eichler</fullName>, which has nearly identical flowers and inflorescences, but the leaves are extremely leathery and bicolored, the upper surface varnished strikingly, and with a sharply acute apex and massive, flat petiole. Whether <fullName rank="species">P. lamprophyllus</fullName>, as <fullName rank="species">P. redactus</fullName> and other related S American species, has epicortical roots remains to be seen. Such roots, with secondary haustoria, were first reported for <fullName rank="species">P. julianus Rizzini</fullName> (<references><reference>

</reference></references>); other species in the genus are without epicortal roots. Curiously, in the two rooted specimens of <fullName rank="species">P. redactus</fullName> seen (de Granville 4113 and Cordeiro 281, the latter from Mpio. Barcelos, Amazonas, Brazil (LEA)), no secondary haustoria are visble on the epicortical roots, even though one on the former collection is 18 cm long.</string>

<string><subHeading>Distribution:</subHeading> A strictly continental genus, ranging from <distributionLocality class="region">northern Mexico</distributionLocality>, to <distributionLocality class="country">Bolivia</distributionLocality> and <distributionLocality class="region">northern Argentina</distributionLocality>; uncertain number of species (see note below); in the <distributionLocality class="region">Guianas</distributionLocality> 4 species.</string>

Notes: Struthanthus is believed to be polyphyletic, separate species or species groups being derived from distinct branches of Cladocolea. The genus is generally of low-altitude preference. It has never been monographed; the number of species, while uncertain, is at least 50.
Much confusion has existed in the past with regard to the separation of Struthanthus from Phthirusa, but the great majority of species of the former genus are easily recognized in the male plant by its versatile anthers. Uncertainty persists vis-à-vis the boundary of Struthanthus with Cladocolea, and with regard to certain small-flowered Phthirusa species like P. guyanensis and P. trichodes, which do not have the otherwise characteristic anther morphology of Phthirusa.
In the past, it was reported (

</reference></references>) that <fullName rank="species">S. marginatus (Desr.) Blume</fullName> occurs in Guyana. This appears to be incorrect, it is a Brazilian species, only encountered remote from the Guianas.</string>

<text>Anthers 1-locular; lateral vegetative branches with or without basal cataphylls; flowers usually in 1 or 3 series above each fertile bract; if squamate, stems terete</text>

<text>Anthers 2-locular; lateral vegetative branches nearly always with basal cataphylls; flowers in 2 or more series above each fertile bract; if squamate, stems flattened or conspicuously keeled</text>
<char class="habit">Usually small, glabrous bushes, parasitic on dicotyledonous woody plants;
<subChar class="haustoria">haustorial attachments at least initially simple, but cortical strands reaching into host tissues to various distances. </subChar>
succulent, in some species reduced to scales;
<subChar class="arrangement">lowest leafy organs on lateral branches and spikes in median or transverse plane. </subChar>
<char class="lateral branches">Vegetative lateral branches often, but not always, with basal cataphylls, but inflorescences less commonly so. </char>

<char class="inflorescences">Inflorescences |, in axils of leaf scales or foliage leaves, solitary or in clusters, rarely in compound inflorescences, being a spike with a peduncle of at least one internode and one or more terminal,
<subChar class="fertile internodes">fertile internodes with flowers produced, as in <fullName rank="genus">Phoradendron</fullName>, in intercalary fashion; </subChar>
<subChar class="flowers">flower arrangement various but commonly in <subChar class="series">1 or 3 series</subChar> above each fertile bract. </subChar>
<char class="plant sexuality">Monoecious or dioecious, in the former case with diverse patterns of sex distribution on spikes and/or individuals. </char>
<char class="anthers">Anthers |, dehiscing by a transverse slit. <subChar class="locule number">presumedly 1-locular</subChar>, dehiscing by a transverse slit. </char>
<char class="fruits">Fruit commonly |, with persistent perianth segments;

<subChar class="endosperm">endosperm copious, |, as is the weakly differentiated, dicotylous embryo. <subChar class="colour">bright green</subChar>, as is the weakly differentiated, dicotylous embryo. </subChar>

<string><subHeading>Distribution:</subHeading> A neotropical genus of some 120 species, ranging from <distributionLocality class="region">southern Mexico</distributionLocality> and much of the <distributionLocality class="region">Caribbean</distributionLocality> to <distributionLocality class="country">Peru</distributionLocality> and <distributionLocality class="country">Bolivia</distributionLocality>; in the <distributionLocality class="region">Guianas</distributionLocality> 7 species.</string>
<string><subHeading>Habitat:</subHeading> <habitat>on the continent it is characterized by a rather strict preference for <altitude>high elevations</altitude>.</habitat></string>

Notes: Dendrophthora is very closely allied to the much larger genus Phoradendron (see comments under the latter), and a number of species have been transferred from one to the other. The only character which distinguishes the two at present is the 1-locular vs. 2-locular anther, respectively, a character which, notwithstanding its practical problems, seems to be rather consistently reliable: i.e., it at least separates two large, natural assemblages, even though in some species of Dendrophthora not clearly belonging to the "typical" group the validity of this solitary character needs to be tested.
Dendrophthora and Phoradendron do not overlap ecologically nearly as much as their geography would suggest, Phoradendron remaining at low to middle elevations. D. elliptica and D. warmingii would seem to constitute exceptions to this altitudinal pattern of
<refPart class="pubtitle">An update on the genus Dendrophthora (Viscaceae)</refPart>
<text>Leaves < 2.5 x 1 cm; inflorescences < 1 cm long, peduncle simple</text>
<text>Leaves > 2 x 1 cm; inflorescences > 2 cm long, peduncle with 1-3 pairs of basal cataphylls</text>
<text>Leaves linear to very narrowly lanceolate, with very acute apex; fruit ovoid, smooth when young</text>
<text>Leaves broadly obovate to elliptical, apex rounded; fruit globose, often warty when young or fresh</text>
<text>Plants yellowish, percurrent, without intercalary cataphylls; inflorescences axillary only; leaves with rather obscure, palmate venation; Brazil nearly exclusively</text>
<text>Plants green, mostly dichotomous, the few percurrent shoots with intercalary cataphylls; terminal inflorescences present; venation completely obscure; known from Guyana only</text>
<text>Flowers yellow, contrasting with inflorescence axis; inflorescence peduncle ca. 1 cm long; percurrent shoots with 1-3 pairs of intercalary cataphylls</text>
<text>Flowers of same greenish color as inflorescence axis; inflorescence peduncle < 0.5 cm long; intercalary cataphylls absent</text>
<refPart class="pubname">Biol. Chem. Geol. Phys. Med. Sci.</refPart>
<char class="habit">Diffusely branched plants, <subChar class="colour">yellowish to deep green</subChar>;
<subChar class="internodes">internodes terete, <subChar class="length">to 3 cm long</subChar> but mostly much shorter; </subChar>

<subChar class="basal cataphylls">basal cataphylls <subChar class="cataphyll pair number">1 pair</subChar>, <subChar class="relative distance">extremely low (sometimes to 0.3 cm above axil on larger secondary branches)</subChar> and inconspicuous. </subChar>
<subChar class="blade">blade linear to |, acute. <subChar class="shape">narrowly lanceolate</subChar>, <subChar class="dimensions">to 2 x 0.2 cm</subChar>, acute. </subChar>
<char class="plant sexuality">Monoecious, male and female flowers on same inflorescence, former often above latter. </char>
<char class="inflorescences">Inflorescence mostly solitary, <subChar class="length">to 0.4 cm long</subChar>;
<subChar class="fertile internodes">fertile internodes <subChar class="fertile internode number">1 or 2</subChar>; </subChar>
<subChar class="flowers">flowers <subChar class="flower number per bract">1-3</subChar> per fertile bract, <subChar class="series">2- or 3-seriate, rarely 1-seriate</subChar>. </subChar>
<char class="fruits">Fruit <subChar class="colour">white</subChar>, <subChar class="shape">ovoid</subChar>, <subChar class="dimensions">0.25 x 0.2 cm</subChar>,

<string><subHeading>Distribution:</subHeading> <distributionLocality class="region">Tepui summits of Venezuela</distributionLocality> (<distributionLocality class="state">Amazonas</distributionLocality> & <distributionLocality class="state">Bolívar</distributionLocality>); <distributionLocality class="region">Venezuela/Guyana border area</distributionLocality>, <distributionLocality class="region">summit of Mt. Roraima</distributionLocality>; not yet recorded for the <distributionLocality class="region" frequency="absent">Guianas</distributionLocality>.</string>

<string><subHeading>Note:</subHeading> Similar to <fullName rank="species">D. roraimae</fullName> but differing in its larger size and its smaller inflorescences with extremely short peduncles and mostly 2- or 3-seriate flowers.</string>
<char class="habit">Plants <subChar class="colour">dark brown</subChar> when dry, densely leafy;
<subChar class="basal cataphylls">basal cataphylls <subChar class="cataphyll pair number">1 or 2 pairs</subChar>. </subChar>
<subChar class="blade">blade |, about half as wide. <subChar class="shape">ovate-elliptical</subChar>, <subChar class="length">3-6.5 cm long</subChar>, about half as wide. </subChar>

<char class="inflorescences">Inflorescence |, with <subChar class="length">to 2.5 cm long</subChar>, with <subChar class="sterile cataphyll pair number">1 pair</subChar> of sterile cataphylls and <subChar class="fertile internode number">3</subChar>
<subChar class="flowers">flowers <subChar class="flower number per bract">4-6</subChar> per fertile bract, <subChar class="series">3-seriate</subChar>. </subChar>

class="state">Bolívar</distributionLocality>, <distributionLocality class="region">Chimantrá Massif</distributionLocality>), the other the type (<distributionLocality class="locality">Mt. Roraima</distributionLocality>); probably present in adjacent <distributionLocality class="country" status="expected">Guyana</distributionLocality>.</string>

<subChar class="basal cataphylls">basal cataphylls |, in median position. <subChar class="cataphyll pair number">1 pair</subChar>, <subChar class="relative distance">to 0.5 cm above axil</subChar>, in median position. </subChar>
<char class="leaf blades">Leaf blade <subChar class="shape">elliptical to somewhat ovate</subChar>, <subChar class="dimensions">to 2 x 1 cm</subChar>. </char>

<subChar class="fertile internodes">fertile internode |, normally with |, lowest several female. <subChar class="fertile internode number">usually 1</subChar>, normally with <subChar class="flower number per bract">5</subChar> flowers per fertile bract, <subChar class="series">3-seriate</subChar>, lowest several female. </subChar>
<subChar class="colour">white</subChar>, <subChar class="shape">ovoid to nearly spherical</subChar>, <subChar class="dimensions">0.5 x 0.6 cm</subChar>
<subChar class="perianth segments">perianth segments small, <subChar class="growth form">erect</subChar>.</subChar>

<string><subHeading>Distribution:</subHeading> Throughout <distributionLocality class="continental region">montane (mostly western) S America</distributionLocality>, to <distributionLocality class="country">Bolivia</distributionLocality>, sometimes descending to middle elevations; ca. 70 collections studied, of which at least 3 from <distributionLocality class="country">Guyana</distributionLocality> (GU: 3).</string>

<string><subHeading>Distribution:</subHeading> A neotropical genus with at least 234 species; the geographical range is very large, reaching from <distributionLocality class="region">southern U.S.A</distributionLocality>, <distributionLocality class="country">Mexico</distributionLocality>, through <distributionLocality class="continental region">C America</distributionLocality> and the <distributionLocality class="region">Caribbean</distributionLocality> to <distributionLocality class="country">Peru</distributionLocality>, <distributionLocality class="country">Bolivia</distributionLocality>, and <distributionLocality class="region">north-central Argentina</distributionLocality>; in the <distributionLocality class="region">Guianas</distributionLocality> 27 species.</string>

Notes: Phoradendron is an extremely challenging genus, partly because of innumerable uncritical species descriptions in the past, and partly because of inherent complexities. The genus is often decidedly difficult to separate from the closely related genus Dendrophthora, a separation based largely on the latter's 1-locular anther vs. 2-locular in Phoradendron. The anther is extremely small and this criterion makes it technically impossible to place novelties which lack male flowers. A second difficulty is the large number of species of Phoradendron.
Flower seriation is especially important in the genus, and is usually quite constant. However, there are cases where a great deal of caution is needed in interpretation. This is especially so in those cases where some or all fertile internodes have only 3 flowers per fertile bract (1 apical flower and 2 representing lateral series). This pattern is found in P. mucronatum, for example, and there is no way to tell whether, if more flowers had been present, the median series would be represented or not (in other words, whether the inflorescence is 3-seriate or 2-seriate, respectively). In other cases, as in P. obtusissimum, we may encounter some fertile internodes with both 3 (or even 1) and more than 3 flowers per bract; in such cases, we are able to discover the seriation type by inspecting the largest fertile internodes. Occasionally there is a great deal of sexual dimorphism, complicating the construction of keys. The key which follows is based on ascertaining the seriation type wherever possible.

<string><subHeading>Note:</subHeading> <fullName rank="species">P. crassifolium</fullName> is an extremely distinctive species because of its multiple, fertile intercalary cataphylls. While Eichler (1868) refers to and illustrates both the 2-seriate and 3-seriate condition, all specimens seen from western S America and C America appear to be strictly 2-seriate; however, an occasional third series of flowers has been noted in some Brazilian plants.</string>

<string><subHeading>Note:</subHeading> <fullName rank="species">P. dipterum</fullName> is a member of a (perhaps always) hyperparasitic group of species which attack other mistletoes, often (but not exclusively) other species of <fullName rank="genus">Phoradendron</fullName>. Its great variability of leaf size and stem morphology may be related to the different hosts parasitized, or perhaps to their vigor. The expression of the winged character of the stem varies not only from plant to plant, but even within a plant; the lowest lateral internodes are usually wingless, and elsewhere 2-winged and 4-winged internodes are sometimes found on the same individual. Another interesting feature of the group is the fact that secondary stems, lacking basal cataphylls, may sprout from a basal cushion, not found in other species.</string>

<string><subHeading>Note:</subHeading> Similar, and closely related to, <fullName rank="species">P. laxiflorum Ule</fullName> from the eastern Amazonian area, but immediately different in having no intercalary cataphylls. Additionally, <fullName rank="species">P. laxiflorum</fullName> has a very different leaf shape and venation, and its petals are erect (Kuijt 1986: 31). The male inflorescence of <fullName rank="species">P. laxiflorum</fullName> has 5-9 flowers per fertile bract in either 2- or 3-seriate pattern, even on the same plant, and we may expect a similar male inflorescence in <fullName rank="species">P. granvillei</fullName>.</string>

<string><subHeading>Note:</subHeading> Similar in general appearance, especially leaf shape and size, to <fullName rank="species">P. racemosum</fullName>, which ranges through the Guianas, the Caribbean, and northern Brazil. <fullName rank="species">P. racemosum</fullName>, however, is consistently dichotomous (through abortion of its apex), while <fullName rank="species">P. pteroneuron</fullName> is percurrent; and the inflorescence of the former has a peduncle of no more than 2 sterile internodes, while up to 6 are present in <fullName rank="species">P. pteroneuron</fullName>.</string>
